entry.title: Combined summary - 64 bit arithmetic soft fork
entry.summary:
Recent discussions among programmers have focused on optimizing Bitcoin's scripting language. They've debated the handling of `CScriptNum`, advocating for computations with integers of arbitrary width and only detecting overflows when converting to specific types. This requires careful implementation to prevent unexpected behaviors, especially in Elements.
A potential hard fork related to modifications in tapscript leaf versions has raised concerns about its impact on network consensus. The importance of the `SCRIPT_VERIFY_MINIMALIF` flag at the consensus level is being reconsidered, alongside its implications for transaction validation and security.
There's a push for consistency in byte value sizes in literals while allowing exceptions like `OP_0` and `OP_1`. The aim is to simplify numeric computations without compromising policies such as `SCRIPT_VERIFY_MINIMALDATA`. Additionally, the introduction of extra encoding for numbers could streamline soft forks but might complicate the `SCRIPT_VERIFY_MINIMALIF` policy.
The development of new opcodes to handle unsigned numbers and enhance precision is under discussion, potentially reactivating operations like multiplication, left shift, and substring extraction. Building on the existing `CScriptNum` is favored over creating a new number format due to its proven utility. Issues related to overflow detection and the updating of `leaf_version` are recognized, with a focus on maintaining backward compatibility.
Proposed changes to math operations in scripting include accommodating a wider input range and managing overflows with new opcodes like `OP_MUL`. Data encoding preferences are leaning towards little-endian, aiming to maintain simplicity. There's also an emphasis on balancing innovation with stability in the scripting landscape, ensuring exact matches between script interpreters to avoid consensus splits.
The proposal of a new opcode, `OP_ENABLE64BIT`, aims to expand arithmetic operation capacity, leading to discussions about its placement and the risks it poses to consensus mechanisms. The adoption of a `leaf_version` that interprets all arithmetic operations as 64-bit globally is suggested to reduce risk. Concerns regarding witness sizes and endianness conversion complexity have been raised, along with the idea of delineating scripts capable of handling expanded arithmetic.
Debates extend to encoding systems within BIPs, comparing minimal-length big endian versus full-length little endian encodings. Streamlining future versions by mandating the use of 64-bit operations is contemplated, despite some resistance. Incorporating covenant opcodes for satoshi value arithmetic is viewed positively, enhancing the flexibility and functionality of covenants.
The significance of 64-bit arithmetic in programming is underscored by its role in improving various computational operations, reflecting the industry's goal of precision and efficiency. The developer community's interest has led to a BIP proposal, currently open for public review at [BIP proposal link](https://github.com/Christewart/bips/pull/1) and [implementation link](https://github.com/Christewart/bitcoin/pull/2). Early feedback is sought to refine the proposal before broader mailing list discussions.
